trans-unit.source:
References

  • https://www.mcw.edu/-/media/MCW/Education/Academic-Affairs/OEI/Faculty-Quick-Guides/Cognitive-Load-Theory.pdf
  • https://accessibledigitallearning.org/resource/making-lessons-accessible-to-all-learners/
  • https://elearningindustry.com/subjects/accessible-learning
  • https://welearnls.com/designing-for-accessibility-how-to-ensure-inclusive-learning-experiences-for-all/
  • https://eige.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/20190551_mh0219064enn_pdf.pdf

 


Glossary

 

  • Accessibility Checkers: Built-in software tools (e.g., in Word or PowerPoint) that automatically test documents for common errors like missing Alt Text or poor color contrast.
  • Alt Text (Alternative Text): A concise written description hidden behind an image or graphic that is read aloud by screen readers for users with visual impairments.
  • Auditory Learners: Individuals who learn best through listening and sound, often benefiting from audio recordings, lectures, or discussions.
  • Captions (Closed Captions): Text displayed on a video screen that shows the spoken dialogue, benefiting hearing-impaired users and those with low language proficiency.
  • Cognitive Load Theory (CLT): An educational framework explaining how the human working memory processes information; used to design materials that prevent mental overload.
  • Cultural Relevance: Ensuring that all content, examples, and images used in materials feel familiar, respectful, and meaningful to the learner's cultural background.
  • Digital Safety Awareness: The skill of thinking critically about online information, recognizing risks like fraud and phishing, and understanding how to protect personal privacy.
  • Extraneous Load: Mental effort wasted on processing poor design elements (e.g., confusing layouts, busy colors) rather than focusing on the learning content.
  • Iterative Design: The process of continuously creating, testing, and refining materials based on feedback and real-world use rather than treating content as a finished product.
  • Mobile-First Consumption: The principle of designing all digital materials to load correctly, look clean, and be easy to use on a small smartphone screen before considering desktop access.
  • Multimodal Content: Educational material that combines different formats, such as text, images, audio, and video, to accommodate diverse learning styles.
  • Plain Language: A communication technique focused on using short sentences, common words, and active verbs so that readers can understand the message quickly and easily.
  • Universal Design for Learning (UDL): A set of principles used to design materials and instruction from the start to be accessible and engaging for the widest possible range of learners.
  • Visual Hierarchy: The organization of text and visuals (using headings, white space, and font size) to guide the learner's eye toward the most important information.
  • WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines): International standards and guidelines for making digital content accessible to people with disabilities, used as a benchmark for quality and safety.
